cons: This region of the state/country is very laid back. It can be difficult to adjust to not working 12-14 hours a day and instead trying to find non-work things to balance it out.

review_title: Comprehensive regional university with a good reputation
pros: Salisbury University (SU) is a highly-regarded institution within the University of Maryland system offering a comprehensive set of programs across the 5 schools. SU performs well on all U of MD system metrics, and is continually improving it's academic profile (as, for example, students receiving Fulbright scholarships). Faculty are generally collaborative across programs; the administrative staff is efficient and supportive; and the campus provides a pleasant working environment (the grounds are a recognized arboretum). The surrounding area is pleasant, offering plenty of outdoor opportunities to interact with nature, whether at the many beaches or on the Chesapeake bay.
cons: Salisbury is the business hub in this largely rural community--which limits employment opportunities for working spouses. Schools ratings are mixed, although there are high performing options. Salaries tend to be on the low side overall, although SU and the U of MD system have made a concerted effort to redress pay differentials of late.

pros: The environment at SU provides for a good work life balance.  Great coworkers who look out for each other. Management is flexible and fair. Great benefits including plenty of vacation and sick leave, a really good healthcare plan, free tuition for your kids and spouse, and free tuition for the employee. Good 403b retirement plan option where the state contributes a percentage automatically (employee does not have to match).
cons: Salary is not always competitive, but the benefits and vacation time make up for this. Currently SU requires a COVID vaccine or twice weekly testing, which may be a deterrent to some but was not a problem for me.

pros:
-Time to work on homework or relax in between calls/tasks.
-They understand you're a student first. No pressure to come in if you have a test you need to study for or anything else academic related.
-Most of the supervisors are sociable and allow you to get to know them on a personal level.
-Lots of opportunities to work more hours.
-Laid back environment.
cons:
-Occasionally there is drama and when it happens every knows about it (office gossip).
-When a supervisor comes in with a funky attitude, it makes for an uncomfortable environment for the student technicians.
-$10 an hour pay cap for student technicians.

review_title: Good if you don't mind the city/location
pros: The campus is attractive, cost of living low (if you don't need to get out of town a lot) friendly faculty and administration and opportunities for funding and development.  This is an excellent place for a young tenure track faculty for experience and room for growth to prove themselves.
cons: Very difficult if you come from and like a lively, culturally rich environment.  There is very little to do in the region beyond going to the beach and drinking.  For singles, it is a wasteland.  This is also a school that does not value their adjuncts, even when highly qualified and does not understand how to show their appreciation for their valuable contributions. *my ratings reflect MY position - not that of adjuncts.

job_title: Technical Support Assistant in Salisbury, MD
pros: Salisbury University is a great employer with some of the best benefits and culture that I've seen. There is quite a bit of inter office politics that can become overwhelming at times, however you generally feel respected as an employee.
cons: There is no direct path of advancement. Moving between departments (at least in IT) can be fairly difficult. Managers tend to be protective of their employees (for better or for worse).

job_title: Desktop Support Intern in Salisbury, MD
pros: Nice coworkers, decent pay, and the opportunity to learn a lot about the IT world while being a student here at Salisbury University.
cons: The supervisor is extremely passive aggressive and generally unpleasant to work for. In addition, many of the procedures put in place seem completely unnecessary and simply add unnecessary work without the benefits of increased security or ease.

pros: You get good students who really care about their classes.  The good students here would succeed anywhere because they're motivated and work hard.
cons: You get some students who just want a piece of paper without doing any work.  There's a sense of entitlement with many of the bad students.  They are shocked when you don't give them an automatic A.  The president and the provost both need to move on.

pros: It was a great job to have while attaining my degree. It allowed me to gain experience and a strong work ethic that will follow in my future endeavors.
